case_data.name: Moyle v. Contra Costa County
case_data.plaintiff_description: All persons who are currently juveniles or who reached the age of majority within two years of filing this action and who were subjected to a strip search at Contra Costa County Juvenile Hall before September 15, 2005.
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
On June 8, 2005, juveniles at Contra Costa County's Juvenile Hall filed this class action civil rights lawsuit pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. The plaintiffs challenged the Contra Costa County and Contra Costa County Probation Department policy of subjecting juveniles to multiple strip and/or visual body cavity searches. Represented by private attorneys, the plaintiffs alleged that pursuant to the defendants' policies, juvenile detainees in their custody were subjected to strip and visual body cavity searches before they appeared at a detention hearing and without having any reasonable suspicion that the searches would be productive of contraband or weapons. The plaintiffs sought monetary damages, declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as class certification.

The complaint was amended on September 16, 2005 and alleged claims for: 1) violation of Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments and 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983; 2) violation of California's Bane Act, California Civil Code section 52.1(a) and Unruh Civil Rights Act, California Civil Code section 52.1(b), based on alleged use of coercion to deprive Plaintiffs of their rights under article I, section 1, of the California Constitution and California Penal Code section 4030; 3) violation of California Penal Code section 4030.

The plaintiffs subsequently moved for class certification. The defendants opposed certification and moved for summary judgment.

On December 5, 2007, the District Court (Magistrate Judge Joseph C. Spero) denied defendants' motion for summary judgment as to the plaintiffs' federal claims, but dismissed the state law claims. Judge Spero certified the case as a class action, defining the class as:

Class One: All juveniles admitted and housed at Contra Costa County Juvenile Hall during the class period who were strip-searched at intake pursuant to defendants' blanket policy and practice of strip-searching all such juveniles prior to their detention hearings, except for: 1) those who were strip-searched at intake after being admitted for an alleged violation (felony or misdemeanor) involving violence, drugs, or weapons; 2) those who were strip-searched at intake because of a reasonable suspicion that such strip search would be productive of contraband; 3) those who had a prior history of being booked on offenses involving drugs, weapons, or violence; 4) those who were subject to parole or probationary search conditions at the time of the strip search; and 5) those who were transferred from another detention facility and thus were not under the constant supervision of a Contra Costa County employee.

Class Two: All juvenile arrestees in Class One who were strip-searched after visits or court appearances, prior to the detention hearing, during the class period.

The class period for both classes was defined as "all persons who are currently juveniles or who reached the age of majority within two years of filing this action and who were subjected to a strip search at Contra Costa County Juvenile Hall before September 15, 2005." Moyle v. County of Contra Costa, 2007 WL 4287315 (N.D.Cal. Dec 05, 2007).

In September 2009, the parties reached a settlement agreement, and on September 8, 2009, the court granted preliminary approval of the settlement. The defendants agreed to implement a revised search policy. The defendants agreed to pay $100,000 to the class representative and $800,000 in attorney's fees and costs. The defendants also agreed to pay a total of $700,000 for the claims of the class members in accordance with the claims processing procedure established in the settlement. The court retained jurisdiction to enforce the settlement.

In 2014, the parties negotiated and filed a motion to modify the order and judgment of dismissal regarding administration of the remaining funds for payments to class members. On April 29, 2014, the court granted in part and denied in part the motion. The court ordered the plaintiffs to file a status report in two years regarding their progress toward locating the remaining class members who had yet to be paid. The plaintiffs spent those two years searching for additional class members to be paid.

On April 4, 2016, the plaintiffs filed the requested status report. The plaintiffs had been able to locate and make payments to five additional class members, but roughly $13,000 remained in the fund. On April 18, Judge Spero ordered the remaining funds be distributed to Loaves and Fishes, an organization that provided community based food

programs and partner services. The case is now closed.
case_data.summary_short: In 2005, private attorneys filed this class action civil rights lawsuit pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.  The plaintiffs challenged the Contra Costa County and Contra Costa County Probation Department policy of subjecting juveniles to multiple strip and/or visual body cavity searches at Contra Costa County's Juvenile Hall.  The parties settled in 2009 and the defendants agreed to a revise search policy and to pay damages and attorney's fees.

Case 3:05-cv-02324-JCS     Document 1     Filed 06/08/2005     Page 2 of 14(cid:10)
1  PLAINTIFF COMES BEFORE THIS HONORABLE COURT AND ALLEGES: 
2    INTRODUCTION 
This is an action for declaratory and injunctive relief, damages, and punitive 
3 
damages  against  CONTRA  COSTA  COUNTY,  CONTRA  COSTA  COUNTY 
4 
PROBATION  DEPARTMENT,  CONTRA  COSTA  COUNTY  CHIEF  PROBATION 
5 
OFFICER LIONEL CHATMAN in his individual and official capacity, CONTRA COSTA 
6 
COUNTY CHIEF DEPUTY PROBATION OFFICER FOR JUVENILE HALL, OFFICER 
7 
JIM MATHERON, in his individual and official capacity; and DOES 1 THROUGH 100 
8 
(persons sued herein by their fictitious names) for violations of plaintiffsโ constitutional 
9 
rights  resulting  from  application  of  CONTRA  COSTA  COUNTYโs  and  CONTRA 
10 
COSTA  COUNTY  PROBATION  DEPARTMENTโs  policies,  practices,  and  customs 
11 
concerning the use of strip searches and visual body cavity searches in Juvenile Hall.  
12

1 Dodge, Ney, Beatty, Slattery, Pfalzer, Borges & Brothers. 
2 After considering the documents previously submitted by the parties, including the Stipulated 
3 Motion  for  Preliminary  Approval  of  Provisional  Settlement  Class  and  Settlement  of  Class  Action, 
4 together with the extensive exhibits attached thereto; the Application of Plaintiffโs Class Counsel for 
5 Award  of  Attorneys=  Fees  and  Costs;  Plaintiffsโ  Submission  in  Support  of  Final  Approval  of  the 
6 Settlement; the arguments of counsel; and the submission from the Class Claims Administrator, 
7 IT IS NOW ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED AS FOLLOWS: 
8 1.  On September 18, 2009, this Court entered its order preliminarily approving settlement of 
9 the above-captioned class action.  Since the entry of the Court=s Preliminary Order, in accordance with 
10 the Stipulation of Settlement as proved to the satisfaction of the Court, the requisite notice of the 
11 Settlement, with opt-out and objection information, was published in the Contra Costa Times and the 
12 West County Times on November 5, 11, and 18, 2009.  The notice of the Settlement and approved claim 
13 forms, were posted by First Class Mail to the last-known address of each person in the Settlement Class.  
14 Both the published notice and the mailed notice specified that Claim Forms had to be delivered to the 
15 Claims Administrator, postmarked no later than January 19, 2010.  
2.  Both the published and mailed notices specified that any person who chooses to object to 
16
the Settlement, either personally or through counsel, and desired to appear at the Fairness Hearing, was 
17
required to submit a Notice of Intention to appear, together with written arguments in support of any 
18
objection, by January 19, 2010.  No objections have been received by counsel or filed with the Court.   
19
3.  The  Court  is  satisfied  from  all  of  the  memoranda  of  law,  declarations,  and  exhibits 
20
submitted to the Court, that the Stipulation of Settlement is fair, and the Court now finds for the reasons 
21
stated on the record at the hearing on March 19, 2010, that the Stipulation of Settlement is fair and finally 
22
approves it as such.  The Stipulation of Settlement is incorporated herein by this reference as if set out in 
23
full. 
24

25
defined class:

28
their detention hearings, except for: 1) those who were strip-searched at

2 prior history of being booked on offenses involving drugs, weapons, or 
violence; 3) those who were subject to parole or probationary search 
3 conditions at the time of the strip search; and 4) those who were transferred 
from another detention facility and thus were not under the constant 
4 supervision of a Contra Costa County employee. 
5 5.  Persons who previously commenced civil litigation challenging the legality of any strip 
6 search at the Contra Costa County Juvenile Hall during the class period and have prevailed, settled or had 
7 their complaints denied on their merits, and persons who have given timely notice of their election to be 
8 excluded from the Settlement Class are not included in the Settlement Class. 
9 6.  All claims and complaints of the named Representative Plaintiff, together with all persons 
10 in the Settlement Class, are now dismissed with prejudice as to all of the Released Persons, defined to 
11 include all Defendants, their predecessors, successors, and/or assigns, together with past, present and 
12 future officials, employees, representatives, attorneys and/or agents of the County of Contra Costa.  
13 Claims and complaints of such persons are now forever barred, and all Settlement Class Members are 
14 enjoined from asserting against any Released Persons any and all claims which the Settlement Class 
15 Members had, have, or may have in the future arising out of the facts alleged in the complaint. 
16 7.  Each Released Person is released from the claims which any Settlement Class Member 
17 has had or may in the future have against any such Released Persons arising out of the facts in the 
18 complaint.   
19 8.  This Court explicitly finds that the Stipulation of Settlement, which is now made final by 
this Judgment, was entered into in good faith, is fair and reasonable, and adequate, and is in the best 
20
interest of the Class.  The Court expressly finds the amount of attorneyโs fees and costs sought to be fair 
21
and reasonable and expressly approves payment to class counsel, Mark E. Merin of the Law Office of 
22
Mark E. Merin and Andrew C. Schwartz of the firm Casper, Meadows, Schwartz & Cook, in the amount 
23
of Eight Hundred Thousand Dollars ($800,000), as and for attorney fees and reimbursement of costs, for 
24
the representation of Settlement Class Members herein, to be paid as provided in the Stipulation of 
25
Settlement. 
26
9.  The Court further explicitly approves payment from the payment fund of a total of  One 
27
Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000.00) to be distributed to the Representative Plaintiff, Katherine 
28

4 10.  Claims have been submitted and, in accordance with the claims processing procedure 
5 specified in the Stipulation of Settlement, will be reviewed, valued, and paid by the Claims Administrator

Penal Code ยง 4030(p), and California Civil Code ยงยง 52 et seq.; and,

and proper.

                                Defendants. 
4
Plaintiff KATHERINE ERMITANO, individually and on behalf of the settlement class defined 
5
herein, and Defendants CONTRA COSTA COUNTY, CONTRA COSTA COUNTY PROBATION 
6
DEPARTMENT, CONTRA COSTA COUNTY CHIEF PROBATION OFFICER LIONEL CHATMAN, 
7
in his official capacity, CONTRA COSTA COUNTY CHIEF DEPUTY PROBATION OFFICER FOR 
8
JUVENILE HALL, NANCY MILLER, in her official capacity, (hereinafter referred to as โPartiesโ), by 
9
and through their respective counsel, hereby submit the following Stipulation of Settlement. 
10
  I. 
11
  RECITALS 
12
13
WHEREAS on or about June 8, 2005, Plaintiff RUSSELL MOYLE, a minor, filed a class action 
14
complaint against Defendant Contra Costa County (โContra Costaโ) and Chief Probation Officer Lionel 
15
Chatman  and  Chief  Deputy  Probation  Officer  For  Juvenile  Hall,  Nancy  Miller  in  their  individual 
16
capacities.    
17
WHEREAS on or about September 15, 2005, Contra Costa revised the strip search policy and has 
18
implemented a revised search policy (the โRevised Policyโ).  The Revised Policy has been implemented 
19
and remains in place pending the outcome of certain appeals regarding the constitutionality of blanket 
20
strip search policies, including the pending Ninth Circuit en banc review in Bull v. City and County of 
21
San Francisco, Case No. 05-17080, D.C. No. CV-03-01840-CRB (9th Cir. hearing en banc on May 26, 
22
2009.). Copies of the Contra Costaโs Revised Policies relating to the strip search of juveniles at Contra 
23
Costa County Juvenile Hall are attached hereto as Exhibit 1.  
24
WHEREAS on September 16, 2005, Plaintiffs filed a Second Amended Complaint to add a new 
25
class  representative,  Plaintiff  KATHERINE  ERMITANO,  at  that  time  a  minor,  challenging  the 
26
Defendantsโ policy of strip searching juveniles at Contra Costa County Juvenile Hall.  Defendants filed a 
27
timely answer to the First Amended Complaint denying allegations of wrong doing or liability.  
28
\\\ 
2 
STIPULATION OF SETTLEMENT 
Moyle, et al. vs. Contra Costa County, et al.; USDC, No. Dist., Case No. C 05-02324 JCS 

Case 3:05-cv-02324-JCS   Document 123   Filed 09/03/09   Page 3 of 20
 
1 WHEREAS  the  Parties  entered  into  discovery  which  included  exchange  of  documents, 
2 preparation of and responses to requests for production of documents, on site review of juvenile files, and 
3 taking depositions of the Parties and Defendantsโ employees and administrators.  
4 WHEREAS on December 4, 2007, the Honorable Joseph C. Spero, United States Magistrate 
5 Judge for the Northern District of California, issued an order granting preliminary certification to a class 
6 of juveniles subject to the class definition set forth in that order (the โCertification Orderโ).  
7 WHEREAS Plaintiffs voluntary dismissed with prejudice all claims against Defendants Chatman 
8 and Miller, leaving only Contra Costa as the remaining Defendant in this Action.  (See Class Cert. Order 
9 fn. 6 at 10.)   
10 WHEREAS, on July 8, 2009 and July 9, 2009, the Parties participated in settlement mediation 
11 presided over by the Honorable Fern M. Smith (retired).  At the mediation, Contra Costa and Plaintiffs 
12 reached an agreement on a Term Sheet, which was approved by the Contra Costa Board of Supervisors 
13 on July 21, 2009.  The terms reached at the mediation were to be further clarified and incorporated into 
14 this Stipulation of Settlement which, subject to the approval of the Court, will constitute a final and 
15 binding settlement agreement of all individual and class-wide claims (and related claims) alleged in the 
16 action in the manner and upon the terms set forth below and fully resolves the dispute.   
17 WHEREAS, at the time of the mediation, the law applicable to the issue of whether Plaintiffsโ 
18 core claim that Contra Costaโs blanket strip search policy violates the Fourth Amendment may be 
19 impacted by on-going appellate proceedings, including the en banc review in Bull v. San Francisco.  As a 
20 result, the Plaintiffs and Contra Costa reached a compromise and agreed that in the event that blanket 
21 strip search policies involving the intake and placing of a juvenile into the general population at juvenile 
22 detention facility are found to be constitutional or the constitutionality of such policies are determined to 
23 be different from that argued by the Plaintiffs or defined by the Court in its Class Certification Order in 
24 this Action, Contra Costa may modify its existing Search Policy or re-implement its prior policy in 
25 compliance with Ninth Circuit or Supreme Court law, and such further revisions and implementation of 
26 those  policies  shall  be  permitted  by  and  incorporated  into  this  agreement  by  subsequent  written 
27 modification to any final settlement agreement reached in this Action.  
28
\\\ 
3 
STIPULATION OF SETTLEMENT 
Moyle, et al. vs. Contra Costa County, et al.; USDC, No. Dist., Case No. C 05-02324 JCS 

Case 3:05-cv-02324-JCS   Document 123   Filed 09/03/09   Page 4 of 20
 
1 WHEREAS, subject to the terms of the original negotiated Term Sheet and approval by the

4 or class-wide allegations averred in the Second Amended Complaint or Motion for Class Certification, 
5 Contra Costa and Plaintiffs enter into this Stipulation of Settlement.

8

Contra Costa County area, announced on radio stations, posted on billboards, and/or posted in juvenile

booked into Contra Costa County Juvenile Hall prior to that date who had not reached the age of 20 on or

28 Plaintiff, SCMs or Class Counsel of the validity of any fact or defense asserted against them in this action

STIPULATION OF SETTLEMENT

1 or in any other action.  Defendants deny all allegations of wrongdoing and deny any liability to Plaintiff 
2 or to any other Class Members.  The Parties have agreed that, in order to avoid long and costly litigation, 
3 this controversy should be settled pursuant to the terms of this settlement, subject to the approval of the 
4 Court.

  III. 
6
  TERMS AND EFFECT OF STIPULATION OF SETTLEMENT 
7
18.  The Parties will file a proposed stipulated protective order concurrently with the motion

Case No. C 05-02324 JCS with prejudice in the United States District Court for the Northern District of 
15
California.

20.  The Parties agree, solely for the purpose of this settlement and its implementation, that

this action shall proceed as a class action, with the Settlement Class as defined in Paragraph 14, and that

20
21.  SCMs who comply with the requirements set forth in this Stipulation of Settlement will be 
21
paid specified sums determined by the procedures set forth herein in full satisfaction of all claims.   
22
22.  The Stipulation of Settlement, as of the Effective Date, resolves in full all claims against 
23
the Released Persons by all of the SCMs, including the named Plaintiff KATHERINE ERMITANO, 
24
involving violation of their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights or of any other federal, state or 
25

26
relate to the facts alleged in Case No. C 05-02324 JCS filed in the United States District Court, Northern 
27
District of California.  When the Stipulation of Settlement is final, as of the Effective Date, all SCMs, 
28

administration, including all notices to the class and processing, administration and payment of the 
18
SCMsโ claims.  Any Administration costs that exceed $150,000.00 allocated for costs of administration 
19
shall be the sole responsibility of the Plaintiffs. Distribution of the settlement amount is subject to the 
20
following terms and conditions of this Stipulation of Settlement. 
21
34.  The parties understand and agree that, prior to a final Fairness Hearing, Class Counsel will 
22
file an application for approval of attorneyโs fees and reimbursement of costs in the amount of $800,000, 
23
supporting that application with a memorandum of law and attaching exhibits documenting their time 
24
spent on the litigation, and that the Court will have the discretion to award whatever amount it considers 
25
appropriate, but in no event will Defendants be obligated to pay any amount in excess of $800,000. 
26
35.  No payment shall be made to eligible SCMs before the Effective Date.  Claims may be 
27
processed between the date of preliminary Court approval and the Effective Date.  Claims will only be 
28
11 
STIPULATION OF SETTLEMENT 
Moyle, et al. vs. Contra Costa County, et al.; USDC, No. Dist., Case No. C 05-02324 JCS 

Case 3:05-cv-02324-JCS   Document 123   Filed 09/03/09   Page 12 of 20
 
1 paid after all verified Claims have been calculated and all disputes relating to Claims have been resolved.   
2 36.  No payment shall be paid to Class Counsel for fees and costs before the Effective Date as 
3 more fully described in Paragraph 10. 
4 37.  The Parties agree to make an application to the Court to appoint the Claims Administrator 
5 as an officer of the Court for the purpose of implementing the terms of the Stipulation of Settlement.  The 
6 Administrator shall be subject to judicial immunity to the fullest extent permitted by law. 
7
  V. 
8
PROCEDURES FOR RECEIVING PAYMENT  
UNDER THIS SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT 
9
 
 
10
38.  All SCMs who were booked at Contra Costa County Juvenile Hall during the class period 
11
who were strip-searched at intake pursuant to Defendantsโ blanket policy and practice of strip searching 
12
all such juveniles prior to their detention hearings, except for: 1) those who were strip searched at intake 
13
after being admitted for an alleged violation involving violence, drugs, or weapons (VDW offense); 2) 
14
those who had a prior history of being booked on VDW offenses; 3) those who were subject to parole or 
15
probationary search conditions at the time of the strip search; and 4) those who were transferred from 
16
another detention facility and thus were not under the constant supervision of a Contra Costa County 
17
employee, shall receive One Thousand, Seven Hundred Fifty Dollars ($1,750.00) for each such booking, 
18
for a maximum of two (2) bookings. 
19
39.  The Administrator shall determine whether or not a person who has submitted a Claim 
20
Form is an SCM and shall reject claims by persons who are not SCMs. 
21
40.  After  all  claims  have  been  validated  and  values  assigned  to  each  claim,  the  Claims 
22
Administrator will total all claims.  If the total value of all validated claims is equal to or less than Seven 
23
Hundred Thousand Dollars ($700,000.00), claims shall be paid as set out in Paragraph 37.  If the total 
24
value of all validated claims exceeds Seven Hundred Thousand Dollars ($700,000.00), the value of each 
25
claim will be proportionately reduced so that the sum of all validated claims equals Seven Hundred 
26
Thousand Dollars ($700,000.00), and such sums shall be paid out as set out in Paragraph 38. 
27
\\\ 
28
12 
STIPULATION OF SETTLEMENT 
Moyle, et al. vs. Contra Costa County, et al.; USDC, No. Dist., Case No. C 05-02324 JCS 

Case 3:05-cv-02324-JCS   Document 123   Filed 09/03/09   Page 13 of 20
 
1 41.  Upon determination of the total amounts to be paid to all SCMs, the Administrator will 
2 notify the Parties of the amount of money necessary to satisfy all SCMsโ claims and the Defendants will 
3 cause sufficient funds to be deposited in the Administratorโs account within thirty (30) days of such 
4 notice to permit the Administrator to pay the verified claims. 
5 42.  Any  SCM  who  fails  to  submit  a  Claim  Form  completed  in  accordance  with  the 
6 instructions contained therein by the Bar Date or any other Court mandated extension, shall be forever 
7 barred from receiving any payment pursuant to the Stipulation of Settlement.  Such SCM shall in all 
8 other respects be bound by all of the terms of the Stipulation of Settlement, and the judgment entered 
9 herein, including but not limited to the release of all Released Persons of all claims resolved herein.   
10 43.  The Administrator will determine the value to be assigned to each eligible SCMsโ claim 
11 based upon the Administrator=s review of the Claim Forms and the information in the database provided 
12 by Defendants.   
13 44.  Claim Forms of all SCMs who have not attained the age of 18 at the time the Claim Form 
14 is submitted shall be signed by a parent or guardian, or by the minor if the minor does not have ready 
15 access to a parent or guardian at the time the claim form is submitted.  The checks distributed to the 
16 SCMs who have not attained the age of 18 at the time the checks are mailed shall be made out jointly to 
17 the SCM and the parent or guardian, if any, who signs the Claim Form and the parent or guardian will be 
18 instructed that the Court ordered funds are to be placed in a blocked account until the minor turns 18. If 
19 the claim submitted was signed only by a minor SCM and the SCM is under the age of 18 at the time the 
20 checks are mailed, the check will be made payable to the Law Office of Mark E. Merin in trust for the 
21 SCM and mailed to the Law Office of Mark E. Merin to be held in trust for that minor until the minor 
22 attains the age of eighteen (18) at which time the funds shall be distributed to the SCM. 
23
  VI. 
24
  PAYMENT OF DEBTS OWED TO THE COUNTY FROM AWARDS 
25
45.  Any award to SCMs shall be subject to any Debts Owed to the County and child support.  
26
The Defendants shall provide to the Claims Administrator, with a copy to Class Counsel, a list of all 
27
qualified SCMs who have Debts Owed to the County as defined in Paragraph 9 and who submit valid 
28
13 
STIPULATION OF SETTLEMENT

Case 3:05-cv-02324-JCS   Document 123   Filed 09/03/09   Page 14 of 20
 
1 claims, with the amount of the Debt Owed to the County specified.  The Claims Administrator is directed 
2 to deduct from each SCM=s award the amount of the specified Debt Owed to the County, up to a 
3 maximum of fifty percent (50%) of the SCM=s award.  Copies of the information related to the reduction 
4 of claims awards shall be provided to the SCMs with copies to Class Counsel.  Any SCM may submit a 
5 written objection to the Debt Owed to the County within thirty (30) days of the date that settlement 
6 checks are distributed.  The written objection shall specify the grounds for the objection and copies shall 
7 be sent to Class Counsel and Defendantsโ Counsel.  In the event that the SCM, Class Counsel and 
8 Defense Counsel cannot informally resolve the objection then the objection will be submitted to the 
9 Special Master. 
10
  VII. 
11
  GENERAL CLAIM PROCEDURES 
12
46.  To receive payment, an SCM shall be required to submit to the Claims Administrator an 
13
executed Claim Form, signed under penalty of perjury.  If the SCM has not attained the age of 18 by the 
14
time the Claim Form is submitted, the Claim Form must be submitted under penalty of perjury by a 
15
parent or guardian of the SCM if one is readily available to the SCM at the time the Claim Form is 
16
submitted.  If a parent or guardian of an SCM under the age of eighteen (18) is not readily available to 
17
the SCM, the SCM may sign and submit the Claim Form under penalty of perjury. 
18
47.  The Claim Form shall be submitted by first class mail and shall be deemed submitted 
19
upon the date of the postmark thereon. 
20
48.  SCMs who submit claims and whose names appear on the database will be paid by mail at 
21
the  address  specified  on  the  Claim  Form.    The  Representative  Plaintiff  shall  be  deemed  fully 
22
compensated  by  the  distribution  to  her  through  Class  Counsel  of  One  Hundred  Thousand  Dollars 
23
($100,000.00) within thirty (30) days of the Effective Date, and she shall not be permitted or required to 
24
submit a Claim Form.  The check for the Representative Plaintiff shall be made payable to โCasper, 
25
Meadows, Schwartz & Cook, Client Trust Account, Moyle, et al. vs. Contra Costa County.โ 
26

\\\

1   VIII. 
2   EXCLUSION FROM THE SETTLEMENT CLASS 
3
49.  Any potential SCM who wishes to be excluded from the Settlement Class must file a 
4
Request for Exclusion from the class with the Clerk of the Court, on or before the Bar Date or as the 
5
Court may otherwise direct.  An SCM who has not attained the age of 18 at the time the Request for 
6
Exclusion is filed, must file such a request signed by the SCM=s parent or guardian under penalty of 
7
perjury.  The Representative Plaintiff will not request exclusion pursuant to this paragraph. 
8
50.  Any potential SCM who does not timely file a Request for Exclusion shall conclusively be 
9
deemed to have become an SCM and to be bound by this Stipulation of Settlement and by all subsequent 
10
proceedings, orders, and judgments herein. 
11
51.  Any SCM who does not elect to be excluded from the Settlement Class may, but need not, 
12
enter an appearance through his or her own attorney.  SCMs who do not enter an appearance will be 
13
represented by Class Counsel. 
14
52.  The Defendants may, in their sole discretion, withdraw from the Stipulation of Settlement 
15
if the number of Opt Outs exceeds 10.   Defendants will advise the Court of their election within 15 
16
(fifteen)  days  prior  to  the  fairness  hearing.    If  Defendants  withdraw  pursuant  to  this  provision  of 
17
Stipulation of Settlement, the Stipulation of Settlement will be null and void. 
18
  IX. 
19
  OBJECTING TO THE PROPOSED SETTLEMENT 
20
21
53.  Any SCM who does not elect to be excluded from the Settlement Class may, but need not, 
22
submit comments or objections to the proposed settlement.  The Court will enter an appropriate order 
23
setting forth the procedure for SCMs to submit comments or objections to the proposed settlement. 
24
  X. 
25
  ATTORNEYS FEES AND COSTS 
26
27 54.  Class Counselโs award of attorneyโs fees and costs shall be inclusive of any costs and fees 
28 incurred in seeking final approval of this Stipulation of Settlement and the defense thereof in any court or 
15 
STIPULATION OF SETTLEMENT 
Moyle, et al. vs. Contra Costa County, et al.; USDC, No. Dist., Case No. C 05-02324 JCS 

Case 3:05-cv-02324-JCS   Document 123   Filed 09/03/09   Page 16 of 20
 
1 jurisdiction.  Payment will be made as follows:  one half of the total amount of attorneyโs fees and costs 
2 awarded by the Court to Plaintiffsโ Counsel will be paid within thirty (30) days of the Effective Date by 
3 check made payable to the Law Office of Mark E. Merin and delivered to Class Counsel at 2001 P Street, 
4 Suite 100, Sacramento, CA 95811.  The remaining half of the total amount of attorneyโs fees and costs 
5 awarded by the Court to Plaintiffsโ Counsel will be paid at the time of distribution of settlement funds to 
6 the SCMs by delivery of a check made payable and delivered as specified above.   
7
  XI. 
8
  NOTICE 
9
55.  Notice to SCMs defined in Paragraph 15, including a Claim Form with a postage pre-
10
paid return envelope, shall be sent by the Administrator by first class mail, postage prepaid, to all 
11
individuals whose addresses are on record in databases maintained by Contra Costa County Probation 
12
Department and/or to such other, better addresses identified by the Administrator.  Defendants will make 
13
reasonable and good faith efforts to provide such addresses to the Administrator, subject to the protective 
14
order referred to in Paragraph 18.  Both Parties and the Administrator will exercise their reasonable 
15
efforts to update and to verify addresses, including but not limited to addresses of SCMs who are 
16
incarcerated.  Further efforts to locate persons whose claim packets are returned as undeliverable, shall 
17
include, but not be limited to, advanced people finder searches, searches of databases of Contra Costa 
18
County juvenile institutions, databases of local jails and state prison systems, and the use of private 
19
investigation services.  This paragraph shall not limit further appropriate efforts to provide notice, except 
20
that all costs incurred with complying with this or any other notice provision shall be deducted from the 
21
$150,000 amount specified for Claims Administration, and in no event shall Contra Costa be required to 
22
pay any amount that exceeds the total aggregate amount of the $1.75 million agreed to by the Parties in 
23
the Term Sheet.

1   XII. 
2   POSTING OF NOTICE/DELIVERY OF CLAIM FORMS 
3
56.  A Summary Notice in a form substantially similar to that attached hereto as Exhibit 4 
4
shall be posted, prominently, in areas visible to inmates/detainees in the following institutions: Contra 
5
Costa County Juvenile Hall (aka John A. Davis Juvenile Hall), the Orin Allen Youth Rehabilitation 
6
Center  (aka  Byron  Boysโ  Ranch),  the  Chris  Adams  Girlsโ  Center  and  Contra  Costa  County  Jails 
7
including but not limited to the Martinez Detention Facility, the West County Detention Facility, and the 
8
Marsh Creek Detention Facility.  The Summary Notices shall be posted within seven (7) days of the 
9
Court=s preliminary approval of this Stipulated Settlement and be posted continuously until the Bar Date.  
10
The  Administrator  will  make  available  to  Defendants  for  transmittal  to  each  institution  at  which 
11
Summary  Notices  are  published,  sufficient  numbers  of  Claim  Forms  and  prepaid  postage  return 
12
envelopes so that the institutions posting notice may provide Claim Forms and prepaid postage return 
13
envelopes to persons requesting them.  
14
57.  Follow-up reminder post cards shall be sent by the Administrator by first class mail 30 
15
days after the date of mailing of the initial notice described in paragraph 56, to the last known address of 
16
all SCMs who have not returned a Claim Form by that date.   
17
58.  The Administrator shall cause to be published in the Contra Costa Times and the West 
18
County Times, and in such free additional publications calculated to reach the SCMs, once a week in 
19
each of three consecutive weeks notices in a form and manner agreed to by the Parties describing this 
20
settlement, the claims procedure, and the procedure to object and/or to opt-out of the settlement.  If the 
21
Parties cannot agree on the wording of the Notice, the Special Master will determine the content of the 
22
Notice to be published.   
23

24
settlement on each of the following radio stations at least six times during each of three successive 
25
weeks: 
26
94.9 KYLD โ WILD 94.9

106.1 KMEL โ Hip Hop and R&B

60.  The parties shall have the option of making an announcement of the proposed settlement 
3
by posting on two billboards in Contra Costa County for the duration of the claims period, provided such 
4
billboards are available and the costs would not result in the Claims Administration costs exceeding the 
5
budgeted maximum.  To the extent that any cost incurred in Section XII exceed the $150,000.00 allotted 
6
for Administration and Notice, Plaintiffs shall be solely responsible for payment of those additional 
7
costs. 
8
  XIII. 
9
  ADMINISTRATIVE COSTS 
10
11
61.  All  reasonable  costs  incurred  in  the  administration  of  this  Stipulation  of  Settlement 
12
including,  but  not  limited  to,  the fees  of  the  Administrator,  costs  of  disseminating  notice  to  class 
13
members, by mail, publication, or other means agreed to by the Parties, costs of producing notice to be 
14
posted, costs of reviewing and evaluating claims, including the cost of distribution of the monetary 
15
payments  to  the  class  members,  fees,  if  any,  of  the  Special  Master,  and  any  additional  ancillary 
16
administration  fees  will  be  paid  up  to  the  total  amount  of  One  Hundred  Fifty  Thousand  Dollars 
17
($150,000.00) allocated for these expenses.  Any Administrative Costs that exceed $150,000.00 shall be 
18
the sole responsibility of Plaintiffs or their Counsel.  In no event shall Contra Costa have any obligation 
19
to incur costs or make any additional payments of administrative costs that exceed the one time payment 
20
of $150,000.00 allocated for the Administrative Costs in this Stipulation or any Preliminary or Final 
21
Settlement approved by the Court.   
22
62.  Following preliminary Court approval of the Stipulation of Settlement, the Administrator 
23
shall submit monthly invoices to Defendants, with copies to Class Counsel, for services rendered and for 
24
expense reimbursement.  All invoices will indicate the dates upon which services were performed, the 
25
titles of the employees performing the services, the number of hours worked by each title on each date, 
26
the hourly rate for each such title, and the total fee for the services performed.  The rates will be in 
27
accordance with the agreement between the Parties and the Claims Administrator. 
28

2 Fifty Thousand Dollars ($150,000.00), counsel for the Plaintiffs shall pay up to an additional Fifty

4 Administration Fund not exceed One Hundred Fifty Thousand Dollars ($150,000.00) after all Claims 
5 have been paid, and all Administration has been completed, any remaining funds will be returned to

5 WHEREAS, the Stipulation of Set tlement, together with the supporting materials, sets forth the 
6 terms and conditions for a proposed settlem ent and dismissal with prejudice of the pending above-
7 captioned class action against all defendants; 
8 WHEREAS,  the Court has before it and has re viewed  the partiesโ Stipula ted  Motion fo r

11 WHEREAS, the Court is sa tisfied that the term s and conditions set forth  in the Stipulation of 
12 Settlement were the result of good faith, arm sโ length settlement negotiations between competent and 
13 experienced counsel for both plaintiffs  and defendants, after mediation before the Honorable Fern M. 
14 Smith (Retired); 
15 IT IS HEREBY ORDERED AS FOLLOWS: 
16
I.  PRELIMINARY APPROVAL OF SETTLEMENT 
17
1.  The terms of the Stipulation of Settlement are hereby preliminarily approved and the class 
18
is preliminarily certified, subject to further consideration thereof at the Fair ness Hearing provided for 
19
below.  The Court f inds that the settlement is sufficiently within the range of reasonableness and that 
20
notice of the proposed settlement should be given as provided in this Order.  
21
2.  The Court has previously found and now reiterates that plaintiff Katherine Ermitano is an 
22
adequate class representative for the settlement class.  
23
3.  The Court further finds that plaintiffsโ counsel Mark E. Merin of the Law Office of Mark 
24
E. Merin and Andrew C. Schwartz  of the firm Casper, Meadows, Sc hwartz & Cook are adequate class 
25
counsel.  
26
4.  The Court approves the Notice of Proposed Settlement of Class Action Strip Search Case 
27
attached hereto as Exhibit A and further approves the method by which notice is proposed to be given. 
28

1 her official capacity, by and through their counsel, James Fitzgerald, III, of the firm McNamara, Dodge, 
2 Ney, Beatty, Slattery, Pfalzer, Borges & Brothers, and Peter Obstler of the firm Bingham McCutchen, 
3 LLP, have entered into a Stipulation of Settlement intending to resolve all claims raised in this class 
4 action pending in this Court; 
5 WHEREAS, the Stipulation of Settlement, together with the supporting materials, sets forth the 
6 terms and conditions for a proposed settlement and dismissal with prejudice of the pending above-
7 captioned class action against all defendants; 
8 WHEREAS,  the  Court  has  before  it  and  has  reviewed  the  partiesโ  Stipulated  Motion  for 
9 Preliminary Approval of Settlement of Class Action together with the Stipulation of Settlement and 
10 supporting materials; and 
11 WHEREAS, the Court is satisfied that the terms and conditions set forth in the Stipulation of 
12 Settlement were the result of good faith, armsโ length settlement negotiations between competent and 
13 experienced counsel for both plaintiffs and defendants, after mediation before the Honorable Fern M. 
14 Smith (Retired); 
15 IT IS HEREBY ORDERED AS FOLLOWS: 
16
I.  PRELIMINARY APPROVAL OF SETTLEMENT 
17
1.  The terms of the Stipulation of Settlement are hereby preliminarily approved and the class 
18
is preliminarily certified, subject to further consideration thereof at the Fairness Hearing provided for 
19
below.  The Court finds that the settlement is sufficiently within the range of reasonableness and that 
20
notice of the proposed settlement should be given as provided in this Order.  
21
2.  The Court has previously found and now reiterates that plaintiff Katherine Ermitano is an 
22
adequate class representative for the settlement class.  
23
3.  The Court further finds that plaintiffsโ counsel Mark E. Merin of the Law Office of Mark 
24
E. Merin and Andrew C. Schwartz of the firm Casper, Meadows, Schwartz & Cook are adequate class 
25
counsel.  
26
4.  The Court approves the Notice of Proposed Settlement of Class Action Strip Search Case 
27
attached hereto as Exhibit A and further approves the method by which notice is proposed to be given. 
28

14 order, shall be deemed to have waived any such objection by appeal, collateral attack, or otherwise.  
15 23.  Persons wishing to be heard at the Fairness Hearing are required to file written comments 
16 or objections and indicate in their written comments or objections their intention to appear at the Fairness 
17 Hearing. Settlement class members need not appear at the hearing or take any other action to indicate 
18 their approval.  
19 24.  All members of the settlement class who do not personally and timely request to be 
20 excluded from the class are enjoined from proceeding against the defendants until such time as the Court 
21 renders a final decision regarding approval of the settlement and, if the settlement is approved, enters 
22 final judgment as provided in the Stipulation of Settlement. 
23
V.  OTHER PROVISIONS 
24
25.  Upon approval of the settlement provided for in the Stipulation of Settlement, each and 
25
every term and provision thereof shall be deemed incorporated herein as if expressly set forth and shall 
26
have the force and effect of an order of this Court. 
27
 
28

24 This matter came on regularly for a Fairness Hearing on March 19, 2010, in Courtroom A of the 
25 above-entitled Court, the Honorable Joseph C. Spero,  Magistrate Judge presiding.  Plaintiff Class was 
26 represented by Class Counsel Mark E. Merin of th e Law Office of Mark E. Merin and Andrew C. 
27 Schwartz of the firm Casper, Meadows, Schwartz & Cook; Defendants were represented by Peter Obstler 
28 and Jee Young You of the firm  Bingham McCutchen, and James Fitzgerald of the firm  McNamara, 
1 
PROPOSED ORDER AND JUDGMENT OF DISMISSAL 
Moyle, et al. vs. Contra Costa County, et al.; USDC, No. Dist., Case No. C 05-02324 JCS 

Case3:05-cv-02324-JCS   Document145    Filed02/19/10   Page2 of 4
 
1 Dodge, Ney, Beatty, Slattery, Pfalzer, Borges & Brothers. 
2 After considering the d ocuments previously submitted by the par ties, including the Stipulated 
3 Motion  for Prelim inary  Approval of Provisional Set tlement  Class and Settlem ent  of Cl ass  Action, 
4 together with the extens ive exhibits attached thereto; the Application of Plaintiffโs Class Counsel for 
5 Award  of Attorneys =  Fees and   Costs; Plaintiffsโ Subm ission  in Support of Final Approval of the 
6 Settlement; the arguments of counsel; and the submission from the Class Claims Administrator, 
7 IT IS NOW ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED AS FOLLOWS: 
8 1.  On September 18, 2009, this Court entered its order preliminarily approving settlement of 
9 the above-captioned class action.   Since the entry of the Court =s Preliminary Order, in accordance with 
10 the Stipulation of Settlement as proved to th e satisfaction of the Court, th e requisite notice of the 
11 Settlement, with opt-out and objection inform ation, was published in th e Contra Costa T imes and the 
12 West County Times on November 5, 11, and 18, 2009.  The notice of the Settlement and approved claim 
13 forms, were posted by First Class Mail to the last-known address of each person in the Settlement Class.  
14 Both the published notice and the m ailed notice specified that Claim Forms had to be deliver ed to the 
15 Claims Administrator, postmarked no later than January 19, 2010.  
16 2.  Both the published and mailed notices specified that any person who chooses to object to 
the Settlement, either personally or through counsel, and desired to a ppear at the Fairness Hearing, was 
17
required to submit a Notice of Inten tion to appear, together with wr itten arguments in support of any 
18
objection, by January 19, 2010.  No objections have been received by counsel or filed with the Court.   
19
3.  The  Court is satisf ied  from  all of  the memoranda  of law, declarations, and exhibits 
20
submitted to the Court, that the Stipulation of Settlement is fair, and the Court now finds for the reasons 
21
stated on the record at the hearing on March 19, 2010, that the Stipulation of Settlement is fair and finally 
22
approves it as such.  The Stipulation of Settlement is incorporated herein by this reference as if set out in 
23
full. 
24
4.  The โSettlement Classโ means all of thos e persons who are m embers of the following 
25
defined class: 
26
All SCMs who were booked at Contra Costa County Juvenile Hall during 
27
the class period who were strip-searched at intake pursuant to Contra Costa 
Countyโs policy and practice of strip-searching all such juveniles prior to 
28
their detention hearings, except for: 1) those who were strip-searched at 
2 
PROPOSED ORDER AND JUDGMENT OF DISMISSAL 
Moyle, et al. vs. Contra Costa County, et al.; USDC, No. Dist., Case No. C 05-02324 JCS 

Case3:05-cv-02324-JCS   Document145    Filed02/19/10   Page3 of 4
 
1 intake after being admitted for an alleged violation (felony or 
misdemeanor) involving violence, drugs, or weapons; 2) those who had a 
2 prior history of being booked on offenses involving drugs, weapons, or 
violence; 3) those who were subject to parole or probationary search 
3 conditions at the time of the strip search; and 4) those who were transferred 
from another detention facility and thus were not under the constant 
4 supervision of a Contra Costa County employee. 
5 5.  Persons who previously commenced civil litigation challenging the legality of any strip 
6 search at the Contra Costa County Juvenile Hall during the class period and have prevailed, settled or had 
7 their complaints denied on their merits, and persons who have given timely notice of their election to be 
8 excluded from the Settlement Class are not included in the Settlement Class. 
9 6.  All claims and complaints of the named Representative Plaintiff, together with all persons 
10 in the Settlement Class, are now dism issed with prejudice as to all of the Released Persons, defined to 
11 include all Defendants, their predecessors, successors , and/or assigns, together  with past, present and 
12 future officials, employees, representatives, attorneys and/or agents of the County of Contra Costa.   
13 Claims and complaints of such persons are now  forever barred, and all Settlem ent Class Members are 
14 enjoined from asserting against any Released Persons any and all c laims which the Settlem ent Class 
15 Members had, have, or may have in the future arising out of the facts alleged in the complaint. 
16 7.  Each Released Person is released from the claims which any Settlem ent Class Member 
17 has had or m ay in the future have against any such  Released Persons arising out of the facts in the 
18 complaint.   
19 8.  This Court explicitly finds that the Stipulation of Settlement, which is now made final by 
this Judgment, was entered  into in good faith, is fair and reasonabl e, and adequate, and is in the best 
20
interest of the Class.  The Court expressly finds the amount of attorneyโs fees and costs sought to be fair 
21
and reasonable and expressly approves paym ent to class counsel, Mark E. Merin of the Law Office of 
22
Mark E. Merin and Andrew C. Schwartz of the firm Casper, Meadows, Schwartz & Cook, in the amount 
23
of Eight Hundred Thousand Dollars ($800,000), as and for attorney fees and reimbursement of costs, for 
24
the representation of Settlement Class Members herein, to be paid as provided in the Stipulation of 
25
Settlement. 
26
9.  The Court further explicitly approves payment from the payment fund of a total of   One 
27
Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000.00) to be distribute d to the Representative Plaintiff, Katherine 
28
3 
PROPOSED ORDER AND JUDGMENT OF DISMISSAL 
Moyle, et al. vs. Contra Costa County, et al.; USDC, No. Dist., Case No. C 05-02324 JCS

1 Ermitano, as specified in the Stipulation of Settlement.  The Court finds the amount is fair and adequate 
2 in view of the damages suffered by the Representative Plaintiff and the efforts she expended in litigating 
3 this case in the more than five years from the time the original claim was filed.   
4 10.  Claims have been sub mitted and, in acco rdance with the claims processing procedure 
5 specified in the Stipulation of Settlement, will be reviewed, valued, and paid by the Claims Administrator 
6 from funds provided by the Defe ndants as soon as pr acticable following the ef fective date of this 
7 Judgment, meaning the date it is entered and becom es final, but in any event no later than 30 days after 
8 notification by the Claims Administrator that they have evaluated all the claims received and are ready to 
9 disburse settlement.  Such Judgment will be deemed final only upon the expiration of the tim e to appeal 
10 or, if a notice of appeal is filed  in this matter, upon exhaustion of al l appeals and petitions for writ of 
11 certiorari. 
12 11.  The Court reserves continuing and exclusive ju risdiction over the parties in this action, 
13 including Defendants and all Settlement Class Members, to administer, supervise, construe and enforce 
14 the Settlement in accordance with the terms for the mutual benefit of all of the parties. 
15 IT IS FURTHER ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED that the complaint in this action be 
dismissed with prejudice and that judgm ent be and the same hereby is entered pursuant to the terms of 
16
this Order.
